sources.CDC: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention breastfeeding guidelines
sources.AAP: American Academy of Pediatrics breastfeeding policy

tips.title: Early Initiation
tips.content: Begin breastfeeding within the first hour after birth. Early initiation helps establish milk production and promotes bonding.

tips.title: Skin-to-Skin Contact
tips.content: Practice skin-to-skin contact immediately after birth and during the first weeks. This helps regulate baby's temperature, heart rate, and breathing.

tips.title: Frequent Feeding
tips.content: Newborns need to feed 8-12 times in 24 hours. Frequent feeding in the first days helps establish milk supply and prevents jaundice.

tips.title: Proper Latch Signs
tips.content: Look for wide mouth opening, lips flanged out, and rhythmic sucking. You should hear swallowing sounds but no clicking or smacking.

tips.title: Milk Supply Establishment
tips.content: Your mature milk comes in around day 3-5. Feed on demand to establish good supply - the more baby nurses, the more milk you'll produce.

tips.title: Monitor Weight Gain
tips.content: Babies typically lose 7-10% of birth weight in first few days, then regain it by 2 weeks. Consult healthcare provider if concerned.

tips.title: Feeding Patterns
tips.content: Babies may cluster feed in evenings. This is normal and helps increase milk supply for growth spurts.

tips.title: Maternal Nutrition
tips.content: Maintain a balanced diet and stay hydrated. You need about 500 extra calories daily while breastfeeding.

tips.title: Breast Pump Introduction
tips.content: If needed, you can introduce pumping after 3-4 weeks once breastfeeding is well established.

tips.title: Growth Spurts
tips.content: Common growth spurts occur around 2-3 weeks, 6 weeks, and 3 months. Baby may feed more frequently - this is normal.

tips.title: Feeding Duration
tips.content: Feeding sessions may become more efficient, lasting 15-20 minutes as baby gets better at nursing.

tips.title: Feeding and Sleep
tips.content: Night feeding is important for maintaining milk supply. Babies this age still need 1-3 night feeds.

tips.title: Supply Regulation
tips.content: Your milk supply regulates around 6-12 weeks. Your breasts may feel softer - this doesn't mean low supply.

tips.title: Feeding Intervals
tips.content: Feeding intervals may stretch to 2-4 hours as baby's stomach grows and feeding becomes more efficient.

tips.title: Distracted Feeding
tips.content: Around 3-4 months, babies become more aware of surroundings and may be easily distracted during feeds. Find a quiet space if needed.

tips.title: Reverse Cycling
tips.content: Some babies start reverse cycling - feeding less during day, more at night. This often happens when caregivers return to work.

tips.title: Return to Work Preparation
tips.content: If returning to work, start pumping and storing milk 2-3 weeks before. Build a freezer stash gradually.

tips.title: Teething and Nursing
tips.content: Teething may begin around 4-6 months. If baby bites, remain calm, remove from breast, and try again.

tips.title: Introduction of Solids
tips.content: WHO recommends exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months, then complementary foods alongside continued breastfeeding.

tips.title: Breastfeeding with Solids
tips.content: Continue breastfeeding before offering solids. Breast milk remains the primary source of nutrition until 12 months.

tips.title: Iron-Rich Foods
tips.content: Introduce iron-rich complementary foods as baby's iron stores from birth begin to deplete around 6 months.

tips.title: Nursing Positions
tips.content: As baby becomes more mobile, you may need to try different nursing positions. Side-lying or sitting positions may work better.

tips.title: Feeding Frequency Changes
tips.content: As solid food intake increases, nursing sessions may become shorter but remain frequent throughout the day.

tips.title: Illness and Breastfeeding
tips.content: Continue breastfeeding during minor illnesses. Breast milk provides antibodies and comfort to sick babies.

tips.title: Continued Benefits
tips.content: WHO recommends breastfeeding up to 2 years or beyond. Breast milk continues to provide nutrition and immune benefits.

tips.title: Toddler Nursing
tips.content: Toddlers may nurse for comfort, connection, and nutrition. Short, frequent sessions are common.

tips.title: Natural Weaning
tips.content: Weaning can be gradual and child-led. Some children naturally reduce nursing frequency as they grow.

tips.title: Extended Breastfeeding
tips.content: Extended breastfeeding beyond 2 years provides continued immune protection and emotional benefits.

tips.title: Nursing in Public
tips.content: Toddler nursing may become more discreet and predictable, often following routines like before naps or bedtime.

tips.title: Gentle Weaning
tips.content: If choosing to wean, do so gradually. Reduce one feeding at a time to allow your body to adjust milk production.

generalTips.title: Stay Hydrated
generalTips.content: Drink water when you feel thirsty. Keep a water bottle nearby during feeding sessions.

generalTips.title: Seek Support
generalTips.content: Don't hesitate to reach out to lactation consultants, healthcare providers, or support groups when you have questions.

generalTips.title: Rest When Possible
generalTips.content: Get rest when you can. Sleep deprivation can affect milk supply and your overall well-being.
